ICMP:	Ping	and	Traceroute Ping	is	a	utility	to	check	the	reachability	of	a	target	host	and,	at	the	same	time,	measure	the round	trip	time	(RTT)	to	this	host. It	works	by	sending	out	an	ICMP	(echo	request)	packet	and	the	target	host	replies	with	an	ICMP (echo	reply)	packet. Traceroute	is	a	utility	to	debug	networks	by	finding	the	routers	on	the	path	to	a	given destination. To	find	these	routers,	traceroute	sends	out	packets,	e.g.,	ICMP	(echo	request)	packets	or	UDP packets,	and	the	on-path	routers	reply	with	ICMP	(time	exceeded	or	echo	reply)	packets. Additionally,	traceroute	also	measures	the	RTT	to	each	on-path	router. Note	that	the	sending	host	may	run	multiple	traceroute	sessions	in	parallel	and	some	of	these sessions	might	be	for	the	same	destination. BGP	Routing	Stability In	this	question,	we	explore	the	merits	and	drawbacks	of	the	mechanism	that	keeps	BGP	sessions alive.	We	assume	the	following	network	topology	(same	as	on	the	previous	page). We	give	a	simplified	description	of	how	BGP	sessions	are	kept	alive.	Without	loss	of	generality,	let	us focus	on	AS2	and	AS4: 1.	 When	the	BGP	session	is	established,	the	BGP	router	in	AS2	and	AS4	announce	their	Hold	Timer to	each	other.	We	assume	that	the	ASes	use	the	same	Hold	Timer	of	90	seconds. 2.	 When	a	new	message	is	received	by	the	BGP	router	in	AS2	from	AS4,	the	BGP	router	in	AS2 resets	its	Hold	Timer	to	90	seconds.	The	BGP	router	in	AS4	does	the	same	for	messages	received from	AS2. 3.	 Suppose	that	Hold	Timer	reaches	0	for	the	BGP	router	in	AS2,	the	BGP	router	in	AS2	sends	an error	message	to	the	BGP	router	in	AS4	and	closes	the	BGP	connection.	The	BGP	router	in	AS4 has	the	same	behaviour	if	Hold	Timer	on	its	end	reaches	0. The	mechanism	described	above	is	used	to	detect	outages	of	ASes	so	that	the	neighbouring	ASes can	update	the	AS-PATH	they	advertise. In	addition	to	the	AS-PATH	format	you	have	seen	in	the	lecture,	there	is	a	second	AS-PATH format	defined	in	RFC	4271.	The	description	is	as	follows.	Points	i.a,	i.b.1,	and	ii	have	already been	introduced	in	the	lectures.	They	are	only	shown	here	for	completeness.	You	do NOT	have	to	read	them.
